<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 118, 379, 144]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge IGCSE™  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 170, 183, 187]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 193, 366, 210]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 Multiple Choice (Extended)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 246, 507, 263]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 277, 487, 322]]<|/det|>
You will need: Multiple choice answer sheet Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB is recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 337, 228, 352]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 353, 880, 522]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions.- For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D. Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Follow the instructions on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Write in soft pencil.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the multiple choice answer sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.- Do not use correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- Take the weight of \(1.0 \text{kg}\) to be \(10 \text{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10 \text{m/s}^2\)).  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 549, 220, 564]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 565, 806, 613]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- Each correct answer will score one mark. A mark will not be deducted for a wrong answer.- Any rough working should be done on this question paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 375, 818, 394]]<|/det|>
A student splashes water on to her face. Here are three statements about the effects.

<label>P</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 406, 529, 425]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 432, 212, 451]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 432, 564, 451]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 458, 205, 476]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 458, 470, 476]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 488, 371, 505]]<|/det|>

<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 515, 751, 534]]<|/det|>
P and Q only B P and R only C Q and R only D P, Q and R

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 560, 920, 594]]<|/det|>
A bimetallic strip is used to control the temperature of electrical appliances. It is made of two different metals fixed together.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 605, 747, 624]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 780, 134, 797]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 780, 554, 797]]<|/det|>
Metal P contracts more than metal Q on heating.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 806, 133, 824]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 806, 554, 824]]<|/det|>
Metal Q contracts more than metal P on heating.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 833, 133, 851]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 833, 549, 851]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 860, 133, 878]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 860, 549, 878]]<|/det|>
Metal Q expands more than metal P on heating.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 106, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 579, 88]]<|/det|> A student writes three statements about thermocouples. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 101, 222, 119]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[222, 101, 524, 119]]<|/det|> They have a small thermal capacity. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 127, 222, 145]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[222, 127, 640, 145]]<|/det|> They respond very slowly to temperature changes. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 154, 616, 172]]<|/det|> They can measure temperatures above \(500^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 184, 371, 201]]<|/det|> Which statements are correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 212, 138, 230]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 212, 205, 230]]<|/det|> 1 only <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 212, 306, 230]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[311, 212, 373, 230]]<|/det|> 2 only <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 212, 473, 230]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[480, 212, 504, 230]]<|/det|> 1 and 3 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 212, 640, 230]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[648, 212, 720, 230]]<|/det|> 2 and 3 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 257, 106, 275]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 257, 920, 291]]<|/det|> Four blocks are made from different metals. Each block is heated for five minutes with an identical heater. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 303, 512, 320]]<|/det|> Assume there is no energy loss from the blocks. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 333, 675, 351]]<|/det|> The table gives the masses of the blocks and the temperature rises. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 363, 544, 381]]<|/det|> Which metal has the highest specific heat capacity? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 392, 584, 522]]<|/det|>
mass of block/kgtemperature rise/°C
A2.05.0
B2.09.0
C4.05.0
D4.09.0
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 549, 106, 567]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 549, 920, 581]]<|/det|> A scientist measures the air temperature at different heights from the floor in a cave. The results are recorded in the table. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[359, 594, 640, 747]]<|/det|>
height/mtemperature/°C
010
1011
2013
3014
4016
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 759, 630, 777]]<|/det|> Why does altering the height affect the temperature of the air? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 788, 134, 806]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 788, 767, 806]]<|/det|> The molecules in warm air have less energy than the molecules in cool air. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 814, 134, 832]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 814, 760, 832]]<|/det|> The molecules in cool air are further apart than the molecules in warm air. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 841, 133, 858]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 841, 455, 858]]<|/det|> Warm air is less dense than cool air. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 867, 133, 885]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 867, 400, 884]]<|/det|> Cool air rises above warm air.

<label>40</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 381, 551, 401]]<|/det|>
Which equation represents the \(\beta\)-decay of lead-209?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 413, 134, 433]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 413, 401, 437]]<|/det|>
\(^{209}_{82}\mathbf{Pb} + \mathrm{\_}^{0}_{-1}\mathbf{e}\rightarrow \mathrm{\_}^{209}_{83}\mathbf{Bi}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 448, 134, 469]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 448, 401, 472]]<|/det|>
\(^{209}_{82}\mathbf{Pb} + \mathrm{\_}^{0}_{-1}\mathbf{e}\rightarrow \mathrm{\_}^{209}_{81}\mathbf{Tl}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 484, 133, 504]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 484, 401, 508]]<|/det|>
\(^{209}_{82}\mathbf{Pb}\rightarrow \mathrm{\_}^{209}_{83}\mathbf{Bi} + \mathrm{\_}^{0}_{-1}\mathbf{e}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 521, 134, 540]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 520, 401, 545]]<|/det|>
\(^{209}_{82}\mathbf{Pb}\rightarrow \mathrm{\_}^{209}_{81}\mathbf{Tl} + \mathrm{\_}^{0}_{-1}\mathbf{e}\)
